title: Fixes #3419: Disable mocks with an error message
body:
This allows us to avoid the memory leak issues addressed by clearInlineMocks, but track how a mock object might leak out of its creating test, as referenced in https://github.com/mockito/mockito/issues/3419

A follow-up should likely create a JUnit 4 rule that allows this to be called with a message that automatically includes the name of the test that created the mock.

 - [ x ] Read the [contributing guide](https://github.com/mockito/mockito/blob/main/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md)

resolved_issues.title: Accessing a mock after clearInlineMocks could provide much more useful error message.

hints:
Consider using the following names for the new files:
1. src/main/java/org/mockito/exceptions/misusing/DisabledMockException.java
2. src/main/java/org/mockito/internal/framework/DisabledMockHandler.java
Consider using the following identifiers for the new entities:
1. HANDLER: HANDLER is a static instance of DisabledMockHandler used to signal that a mock has been disabled and its handler replaced, preventing further interactions after mock clearing.
2. framework: The identifier 'framework' designates the package namespace for custom handler logic that disables mocks after their lifecycle ends, enforcing error-throwing behavior upon further invocations.
3. DisabledMockException: DisabledMockException is a custom exception type thrown when an attempt is made to interact with a mock object after inline mocks have been cleared, enforcing safe usage boundaries in Mockito.
4. DisabledMockHandler: DisabledMockHandler is a custom handler that disables mocks by throwing a DisabledMockException on access, ensuring that mocks marked as cleared are no longer usable in the framework.

title: Fixes #3219: Add support for static mocks on DoNotMockEnforcer
body:
Fixes #3219
Fix mockStatic bypassing DoNotMockEnforcer
Add (optional) method on DoNotMockEnforcer for static mocks

resolved_issues.title: Mockito#mockStatic(Class<?>) skips DoNotMockEnforcer

hints:
Consider using the following names for the new files:
1. src/main/java/org/mockito/mock/MockType.java
2. src/main/java/org/mockito/plugins/DoNotMockEnforcerWithType.java
Consider using the following identifiers for the new entities:
1. STATIC: STATIC is an enum constant of the custom MockType, representing static mocks for distinguishing mock creation modes and supporting specialized logic in both core implementation and test validation.
2. getTypeToMock: The getTypeToMock identifier refers to a method of the MockCreationSettings interface that provides the class type intended for mocking, ensuring that mock enforcement logic can correctly assess and validate mockability based on the actual target class.
3. getMockType: The getMockType method provides access to the MockType associated with a given mock, enabling code to determine the kind of mock being created or manipulated.
4. MockType: MockType is an explicitly defined enum representing the type of mock (INSTANCE or STATIC) to distinguish mock creation modes and should be supplied when configuring or asserting mock behavior.
5. creationSettings: The identifier 'creationSettings' represents the mock creation settings parameter, conveying all configuration needed to determine whether a type is allowed to be mocked according to the custom mock enforcer logic.
6. INSTANCE: MockType is a custom enum that defines whether a mock object is created as an instance or via static mocking, and should be supplied to mock-related constructors or functions to select the desired mock behavior.
7. mock: The identifier 'MockType' designates an enum that specifies the mode of mock creation (INSTANCE or STATIC), serving as a control for mock behavior selection in both implementation and test cases.

Annotation-based spying on a generic class breaks existing final/inline Spies

title: Deep Stubs Incompatible With Mocking Enum
body:
Mockito can't mock abstract enums in Java 15 or later because they are now marked as sealed.
So Mockito reports that now with a better error message.

If a deep stub returns an abstract enum, it uses in the error case now the first enum literal of the real enum.

Fixes #2984

resolved_issues.title: Deep Stubs Incompatible With Mocking Enum

Fixes #1382. 
Introducing new ParameterResolver for @Captor annotation for MockitoExtension, allowing initialization of ArgumentCaptors with annotation.

resolved_issues.title: Support @Captor injection in JUnit 5 method parameters
resolved_issues.body: There is already an open PR #1350 that proposes and adds support for `@Mock`. This issue is to extend on that PR if / when it gets merged to also support the `@Captor` annotation in method parameters. This would allow to inject method specific generic `ArgumentCaptor` that can't be caught with `ArgumentCaptor.of(Class)`.

3. subprojects/junit-jupiter/src/main/java/org/mockito/junit/jupiter/resolver/MockParameterResolver.java
Consider using the following identifiers for the new entities:
1. SuppressWarnings: The SuppressWarnings annotation is used to suppress compile-time warnings for specific methods, particularly where implementation details intentionally trigger warnings such as unchecked operations, and should be carefully applied to maintain code clarity while avoiding needless warning noise.

title: Make MockUtil.getMockMaker() public Mockito API
body:
The MockitoPlugins interface now provides access to the `MockUtil.getMockMaker()` method.

Fixes #3128

resolved_issues.title: Make MockUtil.getMockMaker() public or public Mockito API
resolved_issues.body:
**Proposal:**

Make the method `org.mockito.internal.util.MockUtil.getMockMaker(String)` public or better part of the public Mockito Plugin-API.
The existing `org.mockito.plugins.MockitoPlugins.getInlineMockMaker()` creates a new `mock-maker-inline` instance when called.

**Reason:**

I am currently working on a [PR for Spock](https://github.com/spockframework/spock/pull/1756), which integrates `Mockito` as a Mocking library into Spock for normal and static mocks.

If I use the public API of `MockitoPlugins.getInlineMockMaker()`, the combination of Mockito and Spock with Mockito leads to strange behavior. E.g. If someone mocks the same static class with Mockito and Spock, the  `mock-maker-inline` gets confused.
The reasons for that is, that two Mockito `InlineDelegateByteBuddyMockMaker` instances try to transform static methods at the same time.

If I use the `MockUtil.getMockMaker()` Spock with Mockito and Mockito will interop nicely with each other and report an error, if the same class is mocked twice. 
So the user can use Mockito-API in Spock-Tests and also Spock-API, which uses Mockito under the hood.

hints:
Consider using the following identifiers for the new entities:
1. getMockMaker: The getMockMaker method provides access to a Mockito MockMaker instance based on a given name or default selection, enabling retrieval and interoperability of various mock maker implementations within the mocking framework.
2. UnsupportedOperationException: UnsupportedOperationException is thrown by the default implementation of getMockMaker(String) in MockitoPlugins to signal that the method must be overridden for proper usage.
